alerts.title: Permanent fire prohibition on Teewah Beach
alerts.description: A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.
alerts.details:
A QPWS imposed fire prohibition is in place in the Cooloola Recreation Area, except at Poverty Point camping area. Campfires must not be lit anywhere else in the recreation area including in the Teewah Beach camping zones 1-7.

This permanent fire prohibition was implemented to reduce the risk of bushfires, protect critical habitat of native wildlife, enhance visitor safety from campfire related injuries and reduce rubbish from non-combustible materials being burnt.

Fully enclosed cooking and heating appliances can still be used in camping areas that meet the below requirements.

  • The appliance must use gas or manufactured fuel (heat beads, briquettes). Manufactured fuel does not include timber or wood.
  • It must be used only for cooking and/or heating.
  • It must be a minimum of 20cm off the ground and more than 2m from flammable materials, which includes vegetation. 
  • It must not have the potential to generate airborne embers, or possibly ignite nearby ground fuels.
  • It must be fully self-contained (heat source enclosed and no exposed flame) and never left unattended when in use.
  • Appliances that are not fully self-contained, such as braziers, are not permitted.
  • All appliances, materials and burnt fuel must be removed from the recreation area on your departure.

On the spot fines of $806 can be issued to people who light fires during a fire prohibition.

Campfires are permitted at Poverty Point camping area and at nearby Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area unless in accordance with all local directions for that area.

For details on the difference between a Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) total fire ban and a QPWS fire prohibition and approved cooking appliances visit the DES Camp fires and cooking web page.

QPWS thanks you for your cooperation while we implement this management change.

alerts.title: George Point toilet removed due to erosion
alerts.description: George Point camping area on the southern coastline of Hinchinbrook Island National Park has been affected by severe erosion due to ongoing high tides over the past several years.
alerts.details:
George Point camping area on the southern coastline of Hinchinbrook Island National Park has been affected by severe erosion due to ongoing high tides over the past several years.

The camping area signage and infrastructure has been washed out and the toilet has been removed.

There is bush camping available nearby if needed by Thorsborne Trail hikers or sea kayakers. Space for camping is available under a large stand of trees approximately 250m to the northeast along the beach (prior to reaching the camping area when hiking from north to south). Please be aware there is no formal camping area and no toilet/pack rack. There is no boat-based camping available.

QPWS is currently reviewing options for the future of the site as part of the Thorsborne Trail Enhancement project.

alerts.title: Camp site booking restrictions due to tidal inundation
alerts.description: Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2026 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.
alerts.details:
Several low-lying camp sites adjacent to Pumicestone Passage on the western side of Bribie Island Recreation Area will be closed on a recurring basis throughout 2026 due to tidal inundation from forecast large high tides.

Affected camp sites include:

  • Lime Pocket camping area - All sites
  • Mission Point camping area - Sites 1-6 
  • Gallagher Point camping area - All sites
  • Poverty Creek camping area - Sites 4, 5 & 6

Please note that tide times and heights are taken from the Brisbane Bar tide chart. This is due to the changes in water flow caused by the northern breakaway section of Bribie Island.

On waterfront sites, campers should, where possible, consider placing tents and camping equipment back from the water’s edge to avoid any inundation from passing boats.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up to date with weather forecasts, conditions and warnings.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Severe Weather Damage - Lamington National Park
alerts.description: As a result of damage from Tropical Cyclone Alfred, some areas in Lamington National Park are closed until declared safe.
alerts.details:
As a result of damage from Tropical Cyclone Alfred, some areas in Lamington National Park are closed until declared safe.

QPWS Rangers are managing the situation and have damage assessment and repair activities in progress.

CLOSED Areas:

Binna Burra section

  • Caves track
  • Illinbah circuit (eastern side) - Closed from the first junction on the Gwongoorool track to the Illinbah bush camp. The western side of the Illinbah circuit (access is from the second junction on the Gwongoorool track) will remain open.  Once visitors reach the Illinbah bush camp, please return via the same track.
  • Coomera circuit - Partial closure from the Coomera Falls lookout to the southern junction (second turn-off) of the Border track - The only access to the Coomera Falls lookout is from the northern junction (first turn-off) on the Border track - once visitors reach the Coomera Falls lookout, please return via the same track.

Green Mountains section

  • Albert River circuit - Partial closure from the northern junction (first turn-off) of the Border track to Echo Point - The only access to Echo Point is from the southern junction (second turn-off) on the Border track.  Once visitors reach Echo Point, please return via the same track.

Remote bush camp sites (including on and off track)

  • Illinbah bush camp (on-track)
  • Darlington remote bush camp (off-track)

OPEN Areas:

Binna Burra section

  • Upper Day-use Area and trailhead visitor facilities, including toilets
  • Rainforest circuit
  • Tullawallal circuit
  • Gwongoorool track
  • Daves Creek circuit
  • Lower Bellbird track
  • Wagawn track
  • Araucaria track
  • Mount Hobwee circuit
  • Ship Stern circuit
  • Coomera circuit - Partially open from the northern junction on the Border track (first turn-off) to the Coomera Falls lookout only - once visitors reach the Coomera Falls lookout, please return via the same track.
  • Upper Ballanjui Falls (please return via the same track)
  • Illinbah circuit (western side) - Open from the second junction on the Gwongoorool track to the Illinbah bush camp - Once visitors reach the Illinbah bush camp - please return via the same track. The eastern side will remain temporarily closed until declared safe.
  • Border track (between Binna Burra and Green Mountains/O'Reilly's)

Green Mountains section 

  • Day-use Area and trailhead visitor facilities, including toilets
  • Rainforest return track
  • Centenary track
  • Morans Falls track 
  • Python Rock track 
  • Box Forest circuit
  • West Canungra Creek circuit
  • Toolona Creek circuit
  • Albert River circuit - Partially open from the southern junction (second turn-off) to Echo Point only - once you reach Echo Point, please return via the same track)
  • Border track (between Green Mountains/O'Reilly's and Binna Burra

Gold Coast Hinterland Great Walks track.

Remote Bush camp sites (including on and off track)

  • Mount Bithongabel bush camp (on-track)
  • Echo Point bush camp (on-track)
  • Rat-a-tat remote bush camp (off-track)
  • Stinson remote bush camp (off-track)
  • Point Lookout remote bush camp (off-track)
  • Running Creek remote bush camp (off-track)
  • Lost World - Saddle remote bush camp (off-track)
  • Lost world - Creek remote bush camp (off-track)

Please refer to the Binna Burra section map and Green Mountains section map for more information on locations.

All camping permits for closed areas are suspended for the duration of the closure.

Commercial tour operators and other permit or agreement holders are not permitted to enter closed areas.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

For your safety please use caution whilst visiting the park.

Facilities will reopen when conditions are considered safe.

Stay up to date with weather forecasts, conditions and warnings.

Refunds can be applied for via your online account at qld.gov.au/camping.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Notice of extended baiting program for feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park, Dryander National Park, Dryander State Forest and Dryander Forest Reserve
alerts.description: The Department of the Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation is undertaking a ground baiting program from 25 March 2025 to 25 March 2026. Manufactured baits will be used to control feral pigs and foxes on Conway National Park (Lot 43 on NPW1144 and Lot 1 on NPW1145), Dryander National Park (Lot 24 on AP19346), Dryander State Forest (Lot 432 on AP19346) and Dryander Forest Reserve (Lot 5 on AP19346). Notices will be placed at the Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service office at Jubilee Pocket and the Whitsunday Regional Council offices at Proserpine and Cannonvale for one week prior to each baiting event. These notices will remain in place for four weeks after baiting has finished. Notices will also be placed at the entrances of the Conway Circuit on Conway National Park and at Double Bay on Dryander National Park. A Park Alert will also be placed on the Department of Environment, Tourism, Science and Innovation website (www.detsi.qld.gov.au) for the same period. Dogs and other domestic animals are not allowed within protected areas. Steps must be taken to ensure domestic dogs do not gain access to the baits or poisoned animals. Neighbours should restrain dogs and other domestic animals during baiting programs. For more information, please contact the department on 13 QGOV (13 74 68).

alerts.title: Exposed sand cliff and dune landslide danger
alerts.description: Exposed sand cliffs and dunes along Teewah Beach, Rainbow Beach and Double Island Point are unstable and can collapse without warning.
alerts.details:
Exposed sand cliffs and dunes along Teewah Beach, Rainbow Beach and Double Island Point are unstable and can collapse without warning.

Falling boulders and landslides are common and can cause serious injury or death.

   • NEVER climb or dig into sand cliffs.

   • Avoid standing, sitting or parking near the base of the sand cliffs.

   • Supervise children at all times

For your safety please use caution whilst visiting the park.

alerts.title: New waste transfer stations for Great Sandy National Park, Cooloola Recreation Area
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) has established new waste transfer stations for Great Sandy National Park, Cooloola Recreation Area.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) has established new waste transfer stations for Great Sandy National Park, Cooloola Recreation Area.

New waste stations are located at the portable toilet waste facility site at:

  • Beach Road, 2nd Cutting, Noosa North Shore
  • Freshwater Road, off Rainbow Beach Road

From 1 July 2025, all visitors to Great Sandy National Park, Cooloola Recreation Area including Teewah Beach, Freshwater and Double Island Point will be required to securely store and transport their waste to the new waste transfer stations. When storing and transporting your waste, ensure it is in sealed containers to prevent negative interactions with wildlife.

Waste bins will also be removed from Dorrigo South camping area at Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area. Bins will continue to be available for Inskip campers at Sarawak West, M.V. Sarawak, M.V. Beagle, M.V. Natone and S.S. Dorrigo camping areas. No bins are available at Pelican Bay camping area, but campers can use bins located at other Inskip camping areas.

For more information click new waste transfer station flier. 

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Thorsborne Trail seasonal closure
alerts.description: The Thorsborne Trail will be closed from 1 January - 28 February due to the high risk of unsafe conditions over this period.
alerts.details:
The Thorsborne Trail will be closed from 1 January - 28 February due to the high risk of unsafe conditions over this period.

Seasonal conditions during these months bring extreme heat and regular heavy rainfall - hikers are often unable to cross creeks and are at the highest risk of heat-related injuries.

Extreme weather events are also more likely during these months.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

alerts.title: Challenging seasonal hiking conditions
alerts.description: Hiking the Thorsborne Trail is considerably challenging during the summer months between October to March.
alerts.details:
Hiking the Thorsborne Trail is considerably challenging during the summer months between October to March.

Conditions are extremely hot and humid at this time of year, increasing the risk of heat-related injuries. Hikers can suffer heat exhaustion.

Freshwater sources often dry up in October-December. The wet season usually begins in December. When the wet season starts, high rainfall can cause creeks to rise rapidly and crossings to become dangerous. Extreme weather events are also more likely during the wet season.

QPWS strongly recommends careful consideration of choosing to undertake the Thorsborne Trail hike during the summer months.     

The Thorsborne Trail is closed seasonally from the start of January to the end of February due to the high risk of unsafe conditions over this period.

alerts.title: Drive with care during marine turtle nesting season
alerts.description: From November to May, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way from nest to ocean for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts to nesting marine turtles.
alerts.details:
From November to May, you may see turtles crossing the beach to lay their eggs or hatchlings making their way from nest to ocean for the first time. Motorists and visitors to Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area are asked to minimise disturbance and human impacts to nesting marine turtles.

When driving on the beach:

  • Plan to travel at 2 hours either side of low tide. Keep to the hard sand well below the high tide line to avoid making wheel ruts that create barriers to hatchling movement down the beach.
  • Avoid driving on the beach at night. This is when turtles will lay their eggs, and hatchlings are most likely to be emerging. Exercise caution and look out for turtles and turtle hatchlings when traversing on the beach.
  • If turtles are making their way across the beach - slow down, stop and wait for the turtles to reach the ocean or the dunes. On-the-spot fines apply to visitors disturbing turtle hatchlings or turtle nests.
  • Driving over vegetated dunes is dangerous and prohibited. It is damaging to the environment and can impact turtle nests, on-the-spot fines apply.

‘Cut the glow to help turtles go’. Artificial lights can affect a turtle’s ability to see the natural horizon over the ocean. Hatchlings can become disoriented, veer from their natural path and head towards the artificial light. When camping during the nesting season you can help cut the glow of lights affecting beaches by switching off unnecessary lights on the beach after 7.30pm.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers.

To report marine animal strandings (of sick, injured or dead turtles, dolphin, dugongs or whales) call the 1300 130 372.

For your safety please avoid interaction with the wildlife.

parks.name: Bribie Island National Park and Recreation Area

alerts.title: Inskip Peninsula camping area boundary realignment and access changes following severe weather damage, combined with shoreline retrogression
alerts.description: A combination of ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred damage, storm surges, swell, and shoreline retrogression has eroded the eastern-facing beaches of Inskip Peninsula, and caused loss of sand, destabilisation of the dunes and loss of existing campground border fencing.
alerts.details:
A combination of ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred damage, storm surges, swell, and shoreline retrogression has eroded the eastern-facing beaches of Inskip Peninsula, and caused loss of sand, destabilisation of the dunes and loss of existing campground border fencing.

A team of geotechnical erosion experts was engaged to investigate the impacts of cyclone events at the Inskip Peninsula Recreation Area and to provide technical advice regarding site safety. Based on the findings and recommendations from the geotechnical assessment, the camping area boundaries will be realigned to establish a 20-metre retrogression buffer zone landward of the current treeline.

This boundary realignment is necessary due to ongoing coastal erosion, nearshore landslide risk, and damage sustained to existing infrastructure. The revised layout will enhance visitor safety by reducing exposure to unstable shoreline areas and future erosion hazards. The following changes apply:

M.V. SARAWAK:

  • Beachfront campsites and the former access track are no longer accessible, including the area known as “Millionaire’s Row”. This location, previously favoured by campers for its open access to solar, firmer surface, and beach proximity, is now closed.
  • Caravans are not suitable in the M.V. Sarawak camping area due to narrow access tracks and stands of cypress and oak trees.
  • When entering M.V. Sarawak, follow all signage and take the first left access track.
  • Do not proceed straight ahead—this route is now a dead end.

M.V. BEAGLE:

  • Beachfront campsites and the former beachfront access track are no longer accessible.
  • Caravans are not suitable in the M.V. Beagle camping area due to narrow access tracks and soft sand.
  • When entering M.V. Beagle, follow the signage and take the first left access track.
  • Do not proceed straight ahead—this route is now a dead end.

M.V. NATONE:

  • The Natone entrance track and eastern low lying camping areas are no longger accessible. Entry and exit to Natone is now through the former exit.
  • Caravans are not suitable in the M.V. Natone camping area due to narrow access tracks, soft sand and inability to turn around.
  • Camping in Natone is suitable to smaller tents and high clearance 4WD only. 

SS Dorrigo and Sarawak West remain the only Inskip camping areas suitable for caravans, requiring a high-clearance caravan towed by a high-clearance 4WD.

Observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers, and do not enter closed areas.

Apply for a camping permit refund online at www.qld.gov.au/camping. Log into your account and cancel your booking to receive an automatic refund or request to change your booking to another camping area at Inskip. 

QPWS thanks you for your support and cooperation.

alerts.title: Dingo (Wongari) Seasonal Information- Dispersal Season
alerts.description: Give dingoes space, Kgari is their place. An increase in dingo-human interactions is expected during the dispersal season.
alerts.details:
Give dingoes space, Kgari is their place. An increase in dingo-human interactions is expected during the dispersal season.

This is a particularly important time for juvenile dingoes (wongari) to test their strength and learn essential survival skills, and to avoid habituation towards people. Juveniles will quickly learn bad habits such as stealing food around camp sites instead of learning natural hunting skills. Take particular care and slow down when driving on K’gari – watch closely for dingoes and other wildlife at all times to ensure they are not harmed.

Visitors, tour operators and residents are advised to be dingo-safe! on K’gari. It is recommended that families with young children camp in fenced QPWS camping areas at Lake Boomanjin, Central Station, Dundubara, Waddy Point and eastern beach fenced areas (Wongai, One Tree Rocks, Cornwells, Eli), or at fenced private camping areas at Dilli Village or Cathedral Beach.

Dispersal season means:

  • Juvenile dingoes are learning pack rules through play and showing aggressive behaviour to gain dominance
  • Young dingoes may try to dominate people, especially children
  • Every time a dingo receives food from people its chance of survival is reduced – let young wongari grow up wild, do not feed them or leave food available

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.detsi.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • NEVER feed dingoes.
  • Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
  • Walk in groups and carry a long dingo safety stick.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Camp in fenced areas when possible.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on boats).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.
  • Secure all rubbish, fish, bait and tackle.
  • No food to lakeshores.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@detsi.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS

ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may apply. Take note of location,

vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number and which ear.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

For further information about wongari (dingoes) on K’gari (Fraser Island) please visit

https://parks.detsi.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Natural Sand Movement and access to Double Island Point
alerts.description: Deep hole formations which may restrict access to and from Double Island Point
alerts.details:
Deep hole formations which may restrict access to and from Double Island Point

Regular sand movement within the saltwater lagoon at Double Island Point often results in the formation of deep holes. These natural changes can prevent vehicles from accessing the Double Island Point (Wide Bay side), the sandspit or travelling through to Rainbow Beach at any tide. This is a natural process within the Great Sandy National Park, where all environments are protected and natural coastal processes are allowed to occur.

Queensland Parks and Wildife Service maintains safe access to the beaches via the Freshwater Track and the Leisha Track.

Always drive the beaches within the Great Sandy National Park to the prevailing conditions. 

Drive two hours either side of low tide. If you are uncertain as to the depth or condition of any hole at any time - do not drive through it.

 

Stay up to date with weather forecasts, conditions and warnings.

Due to the changed conditions the visitor experience may be affected.

For your safety please use caution whilst visiting the park.

alerts.title: Heightened Dingo Activity - K'gari Eastern Beach
alerts.description: QPWS Rangers are urging visitors to be dingo-safe at all times on Kgari after heightened dingo activity has been recorded at several locations along the eastern beach, including:  Beach Camping Zone 4 (Guluri and Eli)  Beach Camping Zone 5 (Wahba and Maheno)  Along the beachfront from Waddy Point north to Ngkala Rocks
alerts.details:
QPWS Rangers are urging visitors to be dingo-safe at all times on Kgari after heightened dingo activity has been recorded at several locations along the eastern beach, including: Beach Camping Zone 4 (Guluri and Eli) Beach Camping Zone 5 (Wahba and Maheno) Along the beachfront from Waddy Point north to Ngkala Rocks

Dingoes have been ripping tents, stealing food or property, damaging property and approaching people. It is recommended that visitors be extra vigilant in these areas and consider camping in a fenced QWPS camping area. Ensure no food or strongly scented items are stored in tents and that all food and rubbish is securely stored in strong lockable containers or vehicles.

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.detsi.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • NEVER feed dingoes.
  • Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
  • Walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Camp in fenced areas when possible.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.
  • Secure all rubbish, fish and bait.
  • No food to lakeshores.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@detsi.qld.gov.au, tell the

nearest QPWS Ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150 – mobile phone charges may

apply. Take note of location, vehicle registration, dingo ear tag colour, number

and which ear.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

alerts.title: Fire prohibition in place for Sundown National Park
alerts.description: Fire prohibition in place for Sundown National Park.
alerts.details:
Fire prohibition in place for Sundown National Park.

Fires must not be lit anywhere in: 

  • Sundown National Park: or 

  • Sundown Resources Reserve.

During the fire prohibition, only fully enclosed cooking and heating appliances that meet the below requirements are permitted. 

The appliance: 

  • Must use gas or manufactured fuel (head beads, briquettes). Manufactured fuel does not include timber or wood. 

  • Must be used only for cooking and/or heating. 

  • Must be a minimum of 20cm off the ground and more than 2m from flammable materials, which includes vegetation. 

  • Must not have the potential to generate airborne embers or possibly ignite nearby ground fuels. 

  • Must be fully self-contained (heat source enclosed and no exposed flame) and never left unattended when in use. Appliances that are not fully self-contained, such as braziers, are not permitted. 

All appliances, materials and burnt fuel must be removed from the area on your departure. 

Visitors must comply with this fire prohibition, on-site signs and any directions given by Rangers. On-the-spot fines may be issued for non-compliance. 

QPWS will continue to monitor the situation and update this Park Alert should conditions change. 

To report any wildfires, call Triple Zero (000) 

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

For your safety please obey all fire restrictions.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Pest Management Control Program - Southend Conservation Park, Curtis Island National Park, Conservation Park, and State Forest.
alerts.description: Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) are planning to conduct a Feral Animal Control Program from Monday 2 February to Wednesday 11 February 2026. The program will include leghold trapping in the southern section of Curtis Island National Park and Southend Conservation Park targeting foxes, wild dogs, and feral cats. Additionally, ground shooting activities targeting feral pigs will be undertaken further north within Curtis Island National Park, Curtis Island Conservation Park, and Curtis Island State Forest.
alerts.details:
Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service (QPWS) are planning to conduct a Feral Animal Control Program from Monday 2 February to Wednesday 11 February 2026. The program will include leghold trapping in the southern section of Curtis Island National Park and Southend Conservation Park targeting foxes, wild dogs, and feral cats. Additionally, ground shooting activities targeting feral pigs will be undertaken further north within Curtis Island National Park, Curtis Island Conservation Park, and Curtis Island State Forest.

These measures are being implemented to protect Flatback Turtle and Yellow Chat habitats and to reduce predation by feral animals, including foxes, wild dogs, feral cats and feral pigs. QPWS will be installing a number of warning signs within the area informing residents and visitors that traps and Firearms will be used within the dune system and other areas within Southend Conservation Park.

To ensure the safety of the public, the following areas are temporarily closed for the duration of the pest management program:

  • Multi Use Trails 1 and 2
  • No access is permitted in the Southend Conservation Park and Southern National Park above the high-water mark
  • The protected areas North or West of Joey Lees Campground and Access road, or South of Yellow Patch Campground during the above dates. 

Access will remain open to Campgrounds and Day Use Areas via main roads and tracks to Joey Lees Campground, North Turtle Street Day Use Area, Turtle Street Campground, Connor Bluff Day use Area, Graham Creek Boat Ramp, Ship Hill Lookout and Multi use Trails excluding Trails 1 and 2. 

Should you have any queries in relation to this matter, please call 0400 381 244.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Facilities will reopen when the event is completed.

alerts.title: Beach camping zone 5  Maheno and Wahba CLOSED
alerts.description: Beach camping zone 5 (Maheno and Wahba) is temporarily closed until 28 Feb 2026. This temporary closure is required due to heightened risk of a habituated dingo pack damaging property, ripping tents, and accessing food from unsecured eskies and fridges.
alerts.details:
Beach camping zone 5 (Maheno and Wahba) is temporarily closed until 28 Feb 2026. This temporary closure is required due to heightened risk of a habituated dingo pack damaging property, ripping tents, and accessing food from unsecured eskies and fridges.

If you have an existing booking please cancel and rebook in another camping area or request a refund online for your existing Queensland National Parks camping or vehicle access booking/s. Please do so via  parks.desi.qld.gov.au/camping/how-to-make-a-booking/cancel-a-camping-booking. 

Alternate camping areas, subject to booking availability, include Beach Camping Zones 2 (One Tree Rocks, Cornwells and Gabala), 3 (Poyungan and Winnum), 6 (Eugarie, Yurru and Guruman) or 7 (Wyuna and Burad).

Families with children are encouraged to stay in fenced camping areas (Waddy Point Top, Wongai, One Tree Rocks, Cornwells, Eli Creek, Dundubara).

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.detsi.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe
•    NEVER feed dingoes.
•    Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
•    Walk in groups and carry a stick.
•    Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
•    Camp in fenced areas when possible.
•    Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
•    Never store food or food containers in tents.
•    Secure all rubbish, fish and bait.
•    No food to lakeshores.
Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@detsi.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest
QPWS Ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

Please visit this park's page on the department's website for more park safety information.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Refunds can be applied for via your online account at qld.gov.au/camping.

alerts.title: Wet season water safety information: Broadwater, Abergowrie State Forest
alerts.description: During the North Queensland wet season local heavy rainfall may cause significant stream rises at Broadwater, Abergowrie State Forest.
alerts.details:
During the North Queensland wet season local heavy rainfall may cause significant stream rises at Broadwater, Abergowrie State Forest.

During and after heavy rain, creek conditions change and become dangerous. Fast flowing, rapidly rising water, with strong currents, occurs. At these times, to stay safe, do not enter the water.

Visitors are urged to use caution at all times around waterways. Always supervise children closely.

Check weather conditions via the Bureau of Meteorology before visiting.

Read more on safety during extreme weather events.

alerts.title: Partial Park closure  Cooloola Wilderness Trail: no pedestrian access across Kin Kin Creek
alerts.description: The Kin Kin Creek pedestrian bridge, which links Elanda Point to Figtree Point on the Cooloola Wilderness Trail, has been washed away during previous flood events. As a result, there is no pedestrian access across Kin Kin Creek currently.
alerts.details:
The Kin Kin Creek pedestrian bridge, which links Elanda Point to Figtree Point on the Cooloola Wilderness Trail, has been washed away during previous flood events. As a result, there is no pedestrian access across Kin Kin Creek currently.

A temporary alternative start and finish point for the Cooloola Wilderness Trail is available at Harry’s Hut or the Boronia Walk. Parking is available at the Boronia Walk trailhead.

Closed areas/walking tracks:
• Cooloola Wilderness Trail – pedestrian access across Kin Kin Creek between   Elanda Point and Figtree Point

Access to Mill Point and Kinaba from Elanda Point is not affected.

QPWS is currently assessing options to restore access.

Swimming across this creek is strongly discouraged due to the presence of submerged objects.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: FENCED Beach Camping Area CLOSURES - Zone 1 (Wongai) and Zone 2 (Cornwells, One Tree)
alerts.description: Rolling temporary closures of 3 fenced camping areas in Beach Camping Zones 1 & 2 on eastern Kgari will take place between Tuesday 10 February and Saturday 28 February 2026 to allow for mesh replacement works to be carried out. At least one of the three affected fenced camping areas will remain open for bookings at different times through this period.
alerts.details:
Rolling temporary closures of 3 fenced camping areas in Beach Camping Zones 1 & 2 on eastern Kgari will take place between Tuesday 10 February and Saturday 28 February 2026 to allow for mesh replacement works to be carried out. At least one of the three affected fenced camping areas will remain open for bookings at different times through this period.

Campground closure periods are as follows:

  • Cornwells fenced camping area (Zone 2) - Tuesday 10/2 to Tuesday 17/2
  • One Tree fenced camping area (Zone 2) - Friday 13/2 to Wednesday 25/2
  • Wongai fenced camping area (Zone 1) - Wednesday 18/2 to Saturday 28/2

Families with children are encouraged to stay in fenced camping areas (Waddy Point Top, Dundubara, Eli Creek, Cornwells, One Tree, Wongai, Central Station, Wathumba).

Be dingo-safe! Visit https://parks.detsi.qld.gov.au/parks/kgari-fraser/about/wongari-dingoes/dingo-safe

  • NEVER feed dingoes.
  • Always stay within arm’s reach of children, even small teenagers.
  • Walk in groups and carry a stick.
  • Do not run. Running or jogging can trigger a negative dingo interaction.
  • Camp in fenced areas when possible.
  • Lock up food stores and iceboxes (even on a boat).
  • Never store food or food containers in tents.
  • Secure all rubbish, fish and bait.
  • No food to lakeshores.

Report dingo encounters – email dingo.ranger@detsi.qld.gov.au, tell the nearest QPWS Ranger, or phone (07) 4127 9150.

Your safety is our concern, but your responsibility.

For a comprehensive list of Park Alerts, visit us at www.qld.gov.au/park-alerts  

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: South Molle Island jetty closed due to cyclone damage
alerts.description: Please be advised that the privately owned jetty located at Bauer Bay, South Molle Island, is closed to the public due to damage caused by Cyclone Koji. The jetty owner has advised QPWS that risk and damage assessments are underway and an estimated reopening date will be advised once repair timeframes are known.
alerts.details:
Please be advised that the privately owned jetty located at Bauer Bay, South Molle Island, is closed to the public due to damage caused by Cyclone Koji. The jetty owner has advised QPWS that risk and damage assessments are underway and an estimated reopening date will be advised once repair timeframes are known.

In the interim, access to the national park from Bauer Bay is via beach landing only and is tide dependant.

Other access points on the island, including Sandy and Paddle Bay remain unchanged.

All visitors may continue to use the designated access path from Bauer Bay beach to access the national park recreational trails. 

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers or resort personnel and do not enter closed areas.

alerts.title: Severe erosion has occurred at the Inskip barge landing beach access tracks due to natural coastal processes and ongoing tidal inundation.
alerts.description: The beach access tracks at the Inskip barge landing have been impacted by natural tidal movement, wave action and coastal erosion, resulting in reduced beach width and destabilisation of the access area.
alerts.details:
The beach access tracks at the Inskip barge landing have been impacted by natural tidal movement, wave action and coastal erosion, resulting in reduced beach width and destabilisation of the access area.

Barge operations and recommended travel times may change in response to tides and weather conditions. Visitors travelling to K’gari via the Inskip barge landing must remain up to date with Mantaray Barge advice prior to departure.

As a result of the erosion, the entrance and exit tracks have merged into a single narrow lane, requiring vehicles travelling in both directions to share the same track. These conditions are most constrained during high tide periods, when available beach width is minimal.

Visitors are strongly advised to plan travel two hours either side of low tide only, proceed with caution through the single-track section, and allow additional time for delays.

Coastal conditions are dynamic and may change rapidly.

Stay up to date with weather forecasts, conditions and warnings.

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

alerts.title: Scheduled dewatering works affecting river levels: Kareeya power station, Tully River, Tully Gorge National Park
alerts.description: From Tuesday 4 August to Friday 5 September 2026 (dates inclusive), CleanCo will undertake dewatering of the Kareeya hydro-power station.
alerts.details:
From Tuesday 4 August to Friday 5 September 2026 (dates inclusive), CleanCo will undertake dewatering of the Kareeya hydro-power station.

This involves removing water from the power station to enable inspections, maintenance and any necessary repairs in areas that are normally inaccessible.

 At the start of the dewatering, there will be a gradual decrease in the Tully River water level. For the duration of the work there will be no water released from the power station and the river level will remain low. Seasonal and natural catchment flows will continue to enter the river and once the dewatering is complete, Tully River levels will return to normal.

 During this time water levels may be affected near the following facilities:

  • Tully Gorge camping area
  • Tully Gorge day-use area
  • Cardstone weir lookout

 For more information on the dewatering works, please contact CleanCo on community@cleancoqld.com.au

alerts.description: The Jourama Falls section of Paluma Range National Park will be closed Friday 6 February to Monday 9 February 2026 (dates inclusive).
alerts.details:
The Jourama Falls section of Paluma Range National Park will be closed Friday 6 February to Monday 9 February 2026 (dates inclusive).

This closure includes the following:

  • Jourama Falls camping area
  • Jourama Falls day-use area
  • Jourama Falls lookout walking track.

This closure is due to wet season rain events, which have made road access unsafe for vehicles and visitors.

For campers with an existing booking between Friday 6 February and Monday 9 February 2026 (dates inclusive)  please cancel and request a refund online.

For your safety, do not enter the area during the closure period.

Please adhere to all safety signage and closure barries during the closure period.

alerts.title: Bushfire alert for Isla Gorge National Park
alerts.description: Due to the current bushfire, Flagstaff Hill lookout area is closed. Bushfire response activities are in progress and QPWS Rangers will continue to manage the situation.
alerts.details:
Due to the current bushfire, Flagstaff Hill lookout area is closed. Bushfire response activities are in progress and QPWS Rangers will continue to manage the situation.

All permits for closed areas are suspended for the duration of the closure. 

Commercial tour operators and other permit or agreement holders are not permitted to enter closed areas. 

Please monitor park alerts on the department's website for updated information.

Please observe all signage, barriers and directions from rangers and do not enter closed areas.

Facilities will reopen when conditions are considered safe.

Stay up-to-date with Current bushfire warnings and incidents from Queensland Fire Department (QFD).

alerts.title: Safety advice: heavy rain impacts Josephine Creek and Falls, Wooroonooran National Park
alerts.description: Visitors are advised that Josephine Creek at Josephine Falls in Wooroonooran National Park is closed until further notice. Heavy rain has resulted in fast flowing, high water levels in Josephine Creek. Further rain is expected. Water levels can change rapidly in Josephine Creek. For your safety, do not enter the water. The walking track and viewing platforms can still be accessed but the creek is closed.
